metadata.sermon_title: The Cry Heard In The Land
metadata.sermon_start_end: Such must be the faith of Christians! The moment we stop believing that there is a power not our own which makes for righteousness we have suspended our participation in the life of Christ. What else has kept us firm against overwhelming odds? Far back in the slave quarters [...] The word is writ as large as the gospel, 'God so loved the world, that he gave his only Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have eternal life' (John 3:16).

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to center on one specific Bible passage. It functions as a thematic speech utilizing various biblical motifs (Exodus, 1 Corinthians, John 3:16) rather than recreating a single pericope into a new word. It lacks the 'nowhere else' specificity Dekker demands.
quotes: The wail of Israel's ancient cry was on their hearts, 'Let my people go.'
not many mighty, not many noble (1 Corinthians 1:26)
The word is writ as large as the gospel, 'God so loved the world...'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., the call of Moses or the crucifixion narrative) and derive the entire movement of the sermon from that specific text alone.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no formal exposition of the original context of the cited verses. The historical context of Israel or the Johannine community is bypassed in favor of immediate metaphorical application to the Montgomery situation.
quotes: The wail of Israel's ancient cry was on their hearts
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Explain the specific historical and theological weight of the 'cry' in Exodus or the 'world' in John 3:16 before applying it to the present.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: Application is the sermon's strongest suit. It is highly concrete, rooted in the Montgomery struggle and the history of American slavery. It avoids generalities by naming specific actors and the zeitgeist of the civil rights movement.
quotes: Far back in the slave quarters our fathers and mothers hummed softly
We are committed in Montgomery to the faith
He died as surely for Pilate as he died for Peter.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application remains tethered to the specificities of the text rather than using the text as a springboard for social commentary.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: While the sermon is not 'boring,' the interwovenness is lopsided because exposition is nearly absent. The hearer is drawn into the contemporary struggle, but the text is not 'expounded' alongside the hearer.
quotes: The cry is still heard in the land.
Here a man and men and women with giant souls in youthful bodies have led some people toward the way of Calvary
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the specific details of the biblical text to dictate the structure of the contemporary application.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The categories of misery (slavery, oppression) and redemption (Calvary, resurrection) are present. However, the 'gratitude' part is somewhat merged into the struggle itself rather than being a distinct response to grace.
quotes: I'm so glad trouble don't last always.
righteousness finds its way to resurrection by facing Calvary.
Mary Magdalene, who poured her gratitude at his feet.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Clarify the distinction between the human struggle for justice and the gratitude awakened by the Spirit as a response to Christ's finished work.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the 'two ways' primarily in terms of temporal loss or gainâ€”the choice between the 'arms of men' and the 'sword of the spirit.' The ultimate seriousness of being lost is present but leans heavily toward the collective/temporal.
quotes: entrusted their lives... not to the arms of men but to the sword of the spirit.
that whosoever believeth in him should not perish
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Deepen the sense of the 'narrow way' as a specific theological calling that involves the possibility of eternal loss, not just social failure.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes the universality of grace and the necessity of the life of Christ for righteousness. It points to salvation outside the self.
quotes: suspended our participation in the life of Christ.
Jesus did not go to his Calvary for his disciples alone.
man is ultimately detached from himself and pointed to salvation outside himself.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is presented not just as an example of 'moral sanity' but as the specific Lord of the text being preached.

8_depth_and_length.findings: The text is far too short to meet Dekker's requirement. At approximately 340 words, it lacks the 'breadth' necessary for homiletical depth. It functions more as an exhortation or a speech fragment than a sermon.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the sermon to at least 2000 words to allow for the 'sleeping' dogmas and exegesis to provide necessary depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of Dekker's definition of a sermon primarily due to its lack of a single specific Bible passage and its insufficient length. It operates as a thematic address where the Bible serves the contemporary narrative rather than the text being recreated into a current word. While the application is concrete and Christ is the telos, the lack of formal exegesis and the brevity prevent it from achieving the 'present of revelation' Dekker describes.
strengths: Concrete application to the specific social and psychological reality of the congregation.
Strong Christocentric focus on the universality of grace.
Effective use of the 'three parts' (misery/redemption) within a historical framework.
weaknesses: Lack of a single underlying pericope; uses the Bible as a source of keywords.
Absence of original language exegesis or historical-critical depth.
Duration is significantly below the 20-minute threshold required for depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: According to Dekker's criteria, this is not a sermon. It is a powerful religious speech or 'actualization of a biblical idea,' but it lacks the formal requirement of being an 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage' with the necessary breadth of 20 minutes.
